newsitem.title: UK: Brazil parallel bond paves way for country - Franco.
newsitem.headline: Brazil parallel bond paves way for country - Franco.

text.p: Brazil's innovative parallel bond will diversify its investor base and pave the way for other borrowers in the country wanting to tap the international bond market, central bank foreign affairs director Gustavo Franco told an investor presentation on Wednesday.
"(The bond) will diversify and broaden Brazil's investor base away from the U.S. investor base and currency (dollar)," Franco said.
"The creation of a large liquid benchmark bonds will pave the way for other Brazilian borrowers to access pan-European investors," he added.
He said Brazil would take advantage of the scarcity of high yielding bonds from good credits.
Brazil is expected to launch a three-tranche bond totalling around $550 to $570 million equivalent.
The parallel bond structure is the first of its kind for an emerging market issuer.
It will have a five-year maturity and be issued in three tranches denominated in French francs, Dutch guilders and Austrian schillings.
All tranches will carry the same coupon and be fungible, or redenominated to the euro after the single European currency is introduced in 1999.
The coupon will be determined at issue, while the benchmark would be the Brazilian 8.875 percent bond due in 2001, issued last November.
Joint lead managers for the transaction are Creditanstalt-Bankverein, ING and Paribas .
Brazil is expected to launch $150 million equivalent in Austrian shillings and $200 million equivalent each in guilders and French francs.
The bonds will be listed in Amsterdam, Paris, Vienna and Luxemburg.
Launch is expected on Monday, April 28.
